Directives: form-for

form-for

form-for(controller, disable, formFor, service, submitComplete, submitError, submitWith, validationFailed, validationRules)

This directive should be paired with an Angular ngForm object and should contain at least one of the formFor field types described below. At a high level, it operates on a bindable form-data object and runs validations each time a change is detected.

Parameters:
Name Type Description
controller Object

Two way bindable attribute exposing access to the formFor controller API. See below for an example of how to use this binding to access the controller.
disable Boolean

Form is disabled. (Note the name is disable and not disabled to avoid collisions with the HTML5 disabled attribute). This attribute is 2-way bindable.
formFor Object

An object on $scope that formFor should read and write data to. It is recommended that you bind to a copied object so that you can quickly revert changes if the user cancels or if submit fails. For more information refer to angular.copy.
service String

Convenience mehtod for identifying an $injector-accessible model containing both the validation rules and submit function. Validation rules should be accessible via an attribute named validationRules and the submit function should be named submit.
submitComplete function

Custom handler to be invoked upon a successful form submission. Use this to display custom messages or do custom routing after submit. This method should accept a "data" parameter. See below for an example. (To set a global, default submit-with handler see FormForConfiguration.)
submitError function

Custom error handler function. This function should accept an "error" parameter. See below for an example. (To set a global, default submit-with handler see FormForConfiguration.)
submitWith function

Function triggered on form-submit. This function should accept a named parameter data (the model object) and should return a promise to be resolved/rejected based on the result of the submission. In the event of a rejection, the promise can return an error string or a map of field-names to specific errors. See below for an example.
validationFailed function

Optional callback to be invoked whenever a form-submit is blocked due to a failed validation.
validationRules Object

Set of client-side validation rules (keyed by form field names) to apply to form-data before submitting. For more information refer to the Validation Types page.
Source:
  • directives/form-for.js, line 1

Members

(static) controller.resetFields

Alias to resetErrors.

Source:
  • directives/form-for.js, line 285

Methods

(static) controller.registerCollectionLabel(fieldName) → {Object}

Collection headers should register themselves using this function in order to be notified of validation errors.

Parameters:
Name Type Description
fieldName String

Unique identifier of collection within model
Source:
  • directives/form-for.js, line 215
Returns:

Object containing keys to be observed by the input field: • error: Header should display the string contained in this field (if one exists); this means the collection is invalid. • required: Header should display a 'required' indicator if this value is true.

Type
Object

(static) controller.registerFormField(fieldName) → {Object}

All form-input children of formFor must register using this function.

Parameters:
Name Type Description
fieldName String

Unique identifier of field within model; used to map errors back to input fields
Source:
  • directives/form-for.js, line 105
Returns:

Object containing keys to be observed by the input field: • bindable: Input should 2-way bind against this attribute in order to sync data with formFor. • disabled: Input should disable itself if this value becomes true; typically this means the form is being submitted. • error: Input should display the string contained in this field (if one exists); this means the input value is invalid. • required: Input should display a 'required' indicator if this value is true.

Type
Object

(static) controller.registerSubmitButton(submitButtonScope) → {Object}

All submitButton children must register with formFor using this function.

Parameters:
Name Type Description
submitButtonScope $scope

$scope of submit button directive
Source:
  • directives/form-for.js, line 197
Returns:

Object containing keys to be observed by the input button: • disabled: Button should disable itself if this value becomes true; typically this means the form is being submitted.

Type
Object

(static) controller.resetErrors()

Resets errors displayed on the

without resetting the form data values.

  • directives/form-for.js, line 267

(static) controller.resetField(fieldName)

Reset validation errors for an individual field.

Parameters:
Name Type Description
fieldName String

Field name within formFor data object (ex. billing.address)
Source:
  • directives/form-for.js, line 250

(static) controller.validateField(fieldName)

Force validation for an individual field. If the field fails validation an error message will automatically be shown.

Parameters:
Name Type Description
fieldName String

Field name within formFor data object (ex. billing.address)
Source:
  • directives/form-for.js, line 293

(static) controller.validateForm()

Validate all registered form-fields. This method returns a promise that is resolved or rejected with a field to error message map.

Source:
  • directives/form-for.js, line 321

(static) this.unregisterFormField(fieldName)

Form fields created within ngRepeat or ngIf directive should clean up themselves on removal.

Parameters:
Name Type Description
fieldName String

Unique identifier of field within model; used to map errors back to input fields
